awd_titl_txt: Language Documentation, Field-work Training Models, and Computational Tools for Understanding Linguistic Stability and Change
awd_abstract_narration:
Proficiency in a shared language is needed for carrying out basic trade and commerce as well as other social functions.  Nevertheless, one can observe established regional varieties at village, city, state, and country levels.  Jeffery Good from the State University of New York at Buffalo, seeks to explain factors such as ethnicity, social class, gender, prestige, and region which help maintain linguistic differences across language or dialect varieties.  It is important to know which factors might destabilize the linguistic balance in a region as these same factors might also lead to other social instability.

Analyzing natural un-prompted language over a three-year period and systematically linking language use to social situations and communication networks, Good will seek explanations for persistent language maintenance, change, or shift in highly multilingual communities of Sub-Saharan Africa, specifically various Bantoid languages of the Lower Fungom region of the Cameroon.  Each language and dialect under study will be documented by local scholars under the supervision of Good and his team.   A new computational tool will be developed to support data management for the vast quantities of raw audio, video, and transcription and translation data gathered by local scholars who will take part in the research. This aspect of the work will produce both computational models and software resources for other documentary projects that seek to employ large teams in data collection.

por.por_cntn:
The project "Language Documentation, Fieldwork Training Models, and Computational Tools for Understanding Linguistic Stability and Change" had four short-term goals that were designed to feed into a longer-term goal. The four short-term goals were: (i) to develop a collaborative training model with partners at Cameroonian institutions to allow students from these institutions to participate directly in research on the country's endangered languages making use of state-of-the-art methods, (ii) to develop tools for data collection to support the distributed, team-based research model adopted by the project, (iii) to develop data collection techniques which capture important features of multilingual speech practices in rural areas, using the Lower Fungom region of Cameroon as research site due to its linguistic diversity and high rates of individual-level multilingualism, and (iv) to collect new language documentation on the languages of Lower Fungom making use of the developing international research network, tools, and techniques developed by the project. The longer-term goal of this research is to better understand the sociolinguistic dynamics of rural regions where traditional patterns of multilingualism still largely prevail. This will be achieved through a longitudinal investigation of language use and change in the Lower Fungom region, which can serve as a microcosm of the linguistic complexities found in many other parts of the world.

Major results of the project included the strengthening of the international collaborative network which has supported not only research on this project but also a number of other projects involving work in Cameroon, the development of an initial version of a smartphone-based app for linguistic data collection, a number of recommendations for how to conduct language documentation in multilingual settings, and an improved understanding of the grammars and sociolinguistic dynamics of the languages of Lower Fungom. Of particular interest is the uncovering of the motivations for multilingualism in this setting, which has applications for work on language development and language maintenance. In particular, project results have shown that, in this region, languages are not associated with deeply held aspects of identity such as ethnicity but, rather, are linked to potentially transitory local political units, such as villages, and people often choose to learn new languages to increase the number of sociopolitical units that they can claim affiliation with.

Both American and Cameroonian students received training and professional development opportunities as a result of this project, with the Cameroonians becoming better acquainted with new methods for documenting their own languages and American students learning about new models of data collection and curation which they will be able to apply to other domains that they may need to work on in the future. While much of the research was based in Cameroon, it has applications to the understanding of patterns of multilingualism all over the world, including within communities in the US characterized by high level of linguistic diversity due to patterns of immigration.
